chapterTitle: Return, Risk, and The Security Market Line

columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to determine the risk-free rate for the two stocks to be correctly priced.

Let's first identify the given amounts in the problem: 

| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Stock Y: ||
|Beta |1.2 |
|Expected return | 11.1%|
|Stock Z:| |
|Beta | 0.80|
|Expected return | 7.85%|

First, let us insert the provided data to the formula from step 3. As an illustration, here's what it looks like: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\text{11.1\%}{- }{R}_{f}}{\text{1.2}}&=\dfrac{\text{7.85\%}{- }{R}_{f}}{\text{0.80}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Then, let us cross multiply both equations. This is done by multiplying the denominator of one fraction by the numerator. This is done to calculate the risk-free rate for both securities.

$$\begin{aligned}
{\text{0.80 $\times$ }}{\text{(11.1\%}{- }{R}_{f}}{{)}}&={\text{1.2 $\times $}}{\text{(7.85\%}{- }{R}_{f}}{{)}}\\
{\text{8.88\%}{- }{0.80R}_{f}}{{}}&={\text{9.42\%}{- }{1.2R}_{f}}{{}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Then, let us rearrange the formula by shifting the risk-free rate to the other side. This is done as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}

{{1.2R}_{f}}{\text{}{- }{0.80R}_{f}}{{}}&={\text{9.42\%}{-8.88\%  }}\\
{\text{0.40R}_{f}}&={\text{0.54\%  }}\\
\end{aligned}$$
**To conclude, a risk-free rate of 1.35% is needed for the two stocks to be correctly priced.**
